dbq_name: Ear Conditions (Including Tinnitus and Hearing Loss)

conditions_covered.description: Ringing, buzzing, or other sounds in the ears
Hearing impairment with vertigo and cerebellar gait

tinnitus_rating.description: Tinnitus is rated at a flat 10% maximum
important_notes: Maximum rating for tinnitus is 10% regardless of severity
Only ONE 10% rating is allowed even if tinnitus is in both ears
Tinnitus is subjective - veteran's description is key evidence
Often service-connected secondary to noise exposure or TBI
One of the most commonly service-connected conditions

hearing_loss_rating.description: Hearing loss rated based on audiometric testing results
hearing_loss_rating.rating_method: Hearing loss is rated using Tables VI, VIA, and VII in 38 CFR 4.85

rating_tables.table_vi: Converts puretone average and speech recognition to Roman numeral designation (I-XI)
rating_tables.table_via: Used when speech recognition is unreliable or exceptional hearing loss patterns exist
rating_tables.table_vii: Combines Roman numerals from each ear to determine percentage rating

hearing_loss_rating.rating_range: 0% to 100% based on combined hearing impairment levels

levels_simplified.description: Mild to moderate hearing loss with good speech recognition
Moderate hearing loss affecting speech understanding
Severe hearing loss significantly affecting communication
Profound hearing loss in both ears
Total hearing loss one ear, near-total other

levels.criteria: Hearing impairment with vertigo less than once a month, with or without tinnitus
Hearing impairment with attacks of vertigo and cerebellar gait occurring from 1 to 4 times a month, with or without tinnitus
Hearing impairment with attacks of vertigo and cerebellar gait occurring more than once weekly, with or without tinnitus

tinnitus: Military noise exposure (weapons, aircraft, vehicles, machinery)
hearing_loss: Comparison of entrance and separation audiograms
Nexus letter connecting hearing loss to service

tips_for_veterans: Describe your tinnitus in detail - sound type, loudness, frequency
Explain how tinnitus affects sleep, concentration, and daily life
Document all military noise exposure (weapons, aircraft, machinery)
Request copies of all in-service audiograms
Describe the worst days for your hearing and tinnitus
Mention if tinnitus interferes with hearing conversations
Document any balance problems or dizziness
Report if you need hearing aids
Explain how hearing loss affects work and relationships
Get buddy statements from fellow service members about noise exposure
common_mistakes: Not describing tinnitus in enough detail
Failing to document military noise exposure
Not mentioning how hearing loss affects daily functioning
Forgetting to report balance or dizziness issues

common_primaries.connection: TBI commonly causes both tinnitus and hearing loss
Associated with tinnitus; noise exposure often causes both
Direct cause of hearing damage and tinnitus

tinnitus_as_secondary.connection: Tinnitus often develops with or after hearing loss
Tinnitus is a symptom of Meniere's

important_notes: Tinnitus maximum rating is 10% regardless of bilateral involvement
Hearing loss ratings are determined by audiometric test results
Veterans should not wear hearing aids during VA audiometric exam
Speech recognition testing uses specific Maryland CNC word list
Tinnitus is one of the most commonly service-connected disabilities
Noise exposure MOSs include infantry, artillery, aviation, armor, maintenance
Hearing loss for VA purposes must meet specific thresholds in 38 CFR 3.385
